answers.answer: The ability of a transport protocol to change its retransmission timer continuously to accommodate variations in internet delay. TCP is the best known protocol that uses adaptive retransmission.

The designations that telephone companies use for the speeds of popular point-to- point digital circuits. DS-0 denotes a digital voice circuit of 64 Kbps; DS-1 denotes 1.544 Mbps; and DS-3 denotes 44.736 Mbps. See Tl, T3.
The protocol an application uses to send data over an ATM network. AAL5, which is part of the ATM stack, accepts and delivers large packets of data (up to 64K bytes).
An alternative to packet switching in which the network hardware forms a circuit between two communicating endpoints. The original telephone network used circuit switching.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking. Note: the acronym CO is also used to refer to a telephone company Central Office. See connectionless.

A computer program, associated with a World Wide Web document, that can generate a document on demand. When a browser requests a dynamic document, the server runs the program and sends the output to the browser. A dynamic document program can generate different output for each request. See active document, static document, and URL.
The IEEE standard for Logical Link Control (See LLC and SNAP.), Ethernet, Token Ring and Wi-Fi wireless network.
A generic reference to any of the services such as ADSL and HDSL that supply broadband data rates over telephone lines.
The method of interaction used when two application programs communicate over a network. A server application waits at a known address, and a client application contacts the server.
A CSMA network that has the capability to detect errors that result when multiple stations transmit simultaneously. See collision.
The algorithm bridges use to avoid a loop.
An algorithm for computing shortest paths in a graph. Routing protocols use Dijkstra's algorithm to compute optimal routes.
A popular application in which a user or computer sends a memo to one or more recipients.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking. Note: the acronym CO is also used to refer to a telephone company Central Office. See connectionless.

An electronic device that connects a leased digital data circuit to computer equipment. The DSU/CSU translates between the digital format used by the telephone companies and the format used by the computer industry. See modem.
The multicast routing protocol used on the MBONE. DVMRP sends multicast locally, but uses IP-in-IP tunneling to transfer multicast datagrams among sites.
A telephone company term for equipment such as a computer that connects to a network. See DCE.
A term used for the original Ethernet because the standard was developed jointly by the three companies.
The scheme used by computers on an Ethernet following a collision. Each computer doubles the time it waits after each successive collision.
A protocol technique in which data is changed by inserting additional bytes to distinguish between data values and packet control values (i.e. headers).
A set of packets transmitted back to back. Packet traffic tends to be bursty.
Access to an FTP server using the login name anonymous and the password guest. Not all FTP servers permit anonymous FTP.

A protocol that computers use to obtain configuration information. DHCP allows a computer to be assigned an IP address without requiring a manager to configure information about the computer in a server's database.
The touch tone encoding used with telephones.
A network system in which a satellite broadcasts all packets and allows individual receivers to discard packets intended for other recipients.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking. Note: the acronym CO is also used to refer to a telephone company Central Office. See connectionless.
One of two basic algorithms used by routing protocols. The alternative to distance vector routing is link-status routing.
The protocol a computer uses to map an IP address into a hardware address. A computer that invokes ARP broadcasts a request to which the target computer re- plies.

A World Wide Web document that is a computer program. After downloading an active document, the browser runs the program on the user's computer. The active document can change the display continuously. See dynamic document, static document, and URL.
The technique in which information to be sent is placed inside the data area of a packet or frame. A packet from one protocol can be encapsulated in another (e.g., ICMP can be encapsulated in IP).
The multicast routing protocol used on the MBONE. DVMRP sends multicast locally, but uses IP-in-IP tunneling to transfer multicast datagrams among sites.
A protocol for propagating multicast routing information.

Characteristic of the original IP addressing scheme in which unicast addresses were divided into three primary classes. The class of an address determines the division between the prefix and suffix in the address. See classless addressing.
A high-speed multiplexing technology used with optical fiber.
The multicast routing protocol used on the MBONE. DVMRP sends multicast locally, but uses IP-in-IP tunneling to transfer multicast datagrams among sites.

A wiring scheme often used with asynchronous serial connections between a pair of computers. One pair of wires is used to carry data in one direction and the other pair is used to carry data in the reverse direction. A 4-wire circuit is usually used to span longer distances than a 3-wire circuit.
A dynamic Web page technology closely linked to Microsoft's Web server. The server interprets Visual Basic code that is embedded in each page whenever the page is requested.

A computer program, associated with a World Wide Web document, that can generate a document on demand. When a browser requests a dynamic document, the server runs the program and sends the output to the browser. A dynamic document program can generate different output for each request. See active document, static document, and URL.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking. See connectionless.
A technology used to control digital cable modems and allow a user to select content.
A telephone company term for communication equipment such as a modem. See DTE. Note: the acronym is also used for Distributed Computing Environment.
The technique in which information to be sent is placed inside the data area of a packet or frame. A packet from one protocol can be encapsulated in another (e.g., ICMP can be encapsulated in IP).

A computer program, associated with a World Wide Web document, that can generate a document on demand. When a browser requests a dynamic document, the server runs the program and sends the output to the browser. A dynamic document program can generate different output for each request. See active document, static document, and URL.
A popular application in which a user or computer sends a memo to one or more recipients.

question.text: EBCDIC (Extended Binary Coded Decimal Interchange Code)

answers.answer: A term used for the original Ethernet because the standard was developed jointly by the three companies.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking. See connectionless.
A telephone company term for the boundary between communication facilities owned by the telephone company and facilities owned by a private organization, See NIU and NTI.
A standard that assigns unique values to 256 characters, including upper and lower case letters, digits, punctuation, and control characters. See ASCII.

The rate at which data can be transmitted across a network. The number of bits per second may differ from the baud rate because more than one bit can be encoded in a single baud. See Gbps, Kbps, and Mbps.
A message used for testing and debugging. An ICMP echo reply is returned in answer to an ICMP echo request message. The ping program receives echo replies. See echo request.
The multicast routing protocol used on the MBONE. DVMRP sends multicast locally, but uses IP-in-IP tunneling to transfer multicast datagrams among sites.

A characteristic of a network system that allows a computer to send data to any other computer at any time. Connectionless networks are analogous to a postal system in which each letter carries the address of the recipient; letters can be sent at any time. See connection-oriented.
The type of connector used with the original, thick wire Ethernet.
A message used for testing and debugging. The ping program sends ICMP echo request messages to elicit echo replies. See echo reply.
The syntactic notation used to express an IPv6 address.

A protocol that a computer uses when it first starts to obtain information needed to configure the protocol software. BOOTP uses IP and UDP to broadcast a request and receive a response before IP has been completely configured.
The touch tone encoding used with telephones.
A standard that assigns unique values to 256 characters, including upper and lower case letters, digits, punctuation, and control characters. See ASCII.
A measure of the capacity of a transmission system. Bandwidth is measured in Hertz.
Term applied to any route propagation protocol used to transfer routing information among Autonomous Systems. See IGP.

A computer program that accesses and displays information from the World Wide Web. A browser contains multiple application programs, and uses an object's name to determine which application should be used to access the object. See URL.
A 32-bit value that specifies how an IP address is divided into network and host portions. Address bits not covered by the mask correspond to the host portion. Also called a subnet mask.
The technique in which information to be sent is placed inside the data area of a packet or frame. A packet from one protocol can be encapsulated in another (e.g., ICMP can be encapsulated in IP).
Characteristic of the current IP addressing scheme in which a 32-bit address mask is used to determine the division between the prefix and suffix of an IP address. See classful addressing.

The short value used when encrypting data to guarantee confidentiality. In some encryption schemes, the receiver must use the same key to decrypt the data. Other schemes use a pair of keys — one to encrypt and a different key to decrypt.
A standard for sending digital information over a cable modem system.

A wiring scheme often used with asynchronous serial connections between a pair of computers. One pair of wires is used to carry data in one direction and the other pair is used to carry data in the reverse direction. A 4-wire circuit is usually used to span longer distances than a 3-wire circuit.
The term telephone companies use to denote a channel configured to handle a voice telephone circuit. ISDN includes B channel service. See D channel.
